metadata.description: National events: Asheville local, North Carolina, Congress, National USA 1933-1957

1933-03-04.description: 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.' New Deal era begins.

1933-03-06.description: All banks closed to prevent further runs. North Carolina banks had closed March 4.

1933-03-09.description: Congress passes act in single day. Gives president control over banking. First New Deal law.

1933-03-13.description: After bank holiday, 5,000 banks reopen. Public confidence restored. Asheville's Wachovia among first.

1933-03-15.description: Cuts federal spending by $500 million. Reduces veterans' benefits and government salaries.

1933-03-22.description: Legalizes beer and wine with 3.2% alcohol. End of Prohibition begins.

1933-03-31.description: Creates jobs for 250,000 young men in conservation work. Many CCC camps in NC mountains.

1933-05-12.description: Pays farmers to reduce production. Aims to raise crop prices. Affects NC tobacco growers.

1933-05-18.description: Congress establishes TVA for flood control, electricity, and economic development.

1933-06-16.description: Creates NRA and PWA. Guarantees workers' right to unionize. End of Hundred Days.
Creates FDIC to insure deposits. Separates commercial and investment banking.

1933-07-15.description: Swannanoa River floods. Roads washed out. Damage estimated at $500,000.

1933-09-25.description: Experimental college opens at Blue Ridge Assembly, 15 miles from Asheville.

1933-11-08.description: City votes 3-1 for legal 3.2% beer. First legal alcohol since Prohibition.

1933-12-05.description: Utah becomes 36th state to ratify. 13 years of Prohibition officially end.

1934-03-01.event: CCC Camp opens in Pisgah Forest
1934-03-01.description: Civilian Conservation Corps establishes camp. 200 young men employed.

1934-06-06.description: Creates Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Joseph Kennedy first chairman.

1934-06-15.event: Great Smoky Mountains National Park established
1934-06-15.description: Park dedicated by FDR. 800 square miles preserved. Major boost for Asheville tourism.

1934-06-28.description: Creates Federal Housing Administration (FHA). Insures home mortgages.

1934-08-15.description: Federal government announces parkway will pass through WNC. Major boost for tourism.

1934-09-11.description: Ground broken near Cumberland Knob. Expected to bring thousands of tourists.

1935-01-01.event: Asheville High School renamed Lee H. Edwards High School
1935-01-01.description: School renamed to honor former superintendent. Building from 1929 construction boom.

1935-03-16.description: City still $40 million in debt from 1920s boom. Negotiations with bondholders continue.

1935-04-08.description: Allocates $4.8 billion. Creates Works Progress Administration (WPA).

1935-05-06.description: FDR creates WPA by executive order. Employs millions in public works, arts, writers projects.

1935-05-27.description: Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States. Court rules NIRA unconstitutional.

1935-06-20.description: Vanderbilt mansion opens doors to tourists. Admission 50 cents.

1935-07-05.event: National Labor Relations Act (Wagner Act) passed
1935-07-05.description: Guarantees workers' right to organize and bargain collectively. Creates NLRB.

1935-08-14.description: FDR signs landmark legislation. Creates old-age pensions, unemployment insurance.

1935-08-30.description: Remnants of hurricane cause severe flooding. Swannanoa valley hard hit.

1936-01-06.description: Butler v. United States invalidates Agricultural Adjustment Act as unconstitutional.

1936-04-06.description: Rare tornado damages buildings in South Asheville. No fatalities.

1936-07-04.description: Temperature reaches 100°F. Hottest day in city's recorded history.

1936-10-15.event: Grove Park Inn hosts Eleanor Roosevelt
1936-10-15.description: First Lady speaks on social issues. Large crowd gathers.

1936-11-03.description: Roosevelt defeats Alf Landon with 60.8% of vote. Carries 46 of 48 states.

1937-01-15.event: WPA Federal Writers' Project active in Asheville
1937-01-15.description: Writers document local history, folklore. Creating guide to North Carolina.

1937-02-05.description: Roosevelt asks Congress to add justices to Supreme Court. Plan fails but Court shifts.

1937-05-28.event: New Asheville High School building opens
1937-05-28.description: Art Deco building completed. Cost $900,000, funded by WPA.

1937-09-02.description: Creates United States Housing Authority. Funds public housing construction.
President Roosevelt passes through en route to Biltmore Estate. Crowds line streets.

1938-02-16.description: New AAA addresses Supreme Court objections. Creates permanent farm support program.

1938-03-15.description: Minor league team begins season at McCormick Field.

1938-06-25.description: Establishes minimum wage (25 cents/hour), 44-hour work week, bans child labor.

1938-09-15.description: Asheville-born novelist dies of tuberculosis at 37. Author of 'Look Homeward, Angel.'

1938-10-03.event: Thomas Wolfe memorial service in Asheville
1938-10-03.description: Hundreds attend memorial for native son. Buried at Riverside Cemetery.

1939-04-03.description: Creates Executive Office of the President. Consolidates New Deal agencies.

1939-05-01.description: New junior college opens. 100 students enrolled.

1939-08-13.description: Heavy rains cause river to overflow. Riverside Drive flooded.

1940-04-15.description: Asheville population 51,310. Buncombe County 82,695. Growth slowed by Depression.

1940-08-29.description: Category 1 hurricane causes flooding. $1 million damage in Buncombe County.

1940-09-16.event: Selective Training and Service Act passed
1940-09-16.description: First peacetime draft in U.S. history. Requires registration of men 21-35.

1940-11-05.description: Roosevelt defeats Wendell Willkie. First president to serve more than two terms.

1940-11-10.event: Asheville Army Reserve called to active duty
1940-11-10.description: Local National Guard units mobilized. 500 men report for training.

1941-03-11.description: Authorizes president to transfer arms to allies 'vital to U.S. defense.' Aid to Britain.

1941-03-20.description: Textile mills running full capacity. Unemployment drops to pre-Depression levels.

1941-12-08.description: Day after Pearl Harbor, Congress votes 82-0 (Senate) and 388-1 (House) for war.
Citizens gather at courthouse. Young men line up at recruiting stations.

1941-12-11.event: Congress declares war on Germany and Italy
1941-12-11.description: After Axis declares war on U.S., Congress votes unanimously for war.

1942-01-30.description: Creates Office of Price Administration. Controls wartime prices and rents.

1942-02-15.description: Sugar rationing starts. Citizens receive ration books at schools.

1942-02-19.description: FDR authorizes military to exclude persons from areas. 120,000 Japanese Americans interned.

1942-06-01.description: Army hospital under construction in Swannanoa. Will treat 3,000 wounded soldiers.

1942-10-15.description: Gasoline rationed to 3 gallons per week. A stickers for essential use only.

1943-04-01.description: 2,000-bed Army hospital receives first patients. Many from North Africa campaign.

1943-06-20.description: Three days of violence. 34 killed, 433 wounded. Federal troops restore order.

1943-07-04.event: Wartime Fourth of July in Asheville
1943-07-04.description: Subdued celebration. No fireworks due to war. Bond rally at Pack Square.

1943-09-15.event: Italian POWs arrive at Asheville camp
1943-09-15.description: Prisoner of war camp established. POWs work on farms and in canneries.

1944-02-22.description: 18 inches of snow. Schools closed. Roads impassable for days.

1944-06-22.description: Servicemen's Readjustment Act provides education, housing, unemployment benefits to veterans.

1944-09-14.description: Great Atlantic Hurricane causes massive flooding. French Broad crests at record 23 feet.

1944-11-07.description: Roosevelt defeats Thomas Dewey. Wins with 53.4% of popular vote.
Buncombe County supports FDR for fourth term. 18,000 to 12,000.

1945-04-12.description: Roosevelt dies of cerebral hemorrhage at Warm Springs, GA. Truman sworn in.
Flags at half-staff. Churches hold memorial services. Schools dismiss early.

1945-05-08.description: Germany surrenders. Church bells ring. Crowds gather at Pack Square.

1945-08-14.description: Emperor Hirohito announces surrender. Celebrations across America. WWII ends.
Japan surrenders. Wild celebration downtown. Horns honking all night.

1945-10-15.description: Army hospital deactivated. Treated 25,000 wounded during war.

1946-02-20.description: Creates Council of Economic Advisers. Commits federal government to full employment goal.

1946-03-15.description: Thousands of GIs returning. Housing shortage acute. GI Bill enrollment surges.

1946-07-04.event: First peacetime Fourth of July since 1941
1946-07-04.description: Fireworks return to Asheville. 20,000 attend celebration at McCormick Field.

1946-08-01.description: Creates Atomic Energy Commission. Transfers nuclear weapons control from military to civilians.

1946-09-01.description: GI Bill brings veterans to experimental college. Enrollment reaches 100.

1946-11-05.description: GOP gains 55 House seats, 12 Senate seats. First Republican Congress since 1930.

1946-12-01.description: ACT established. First production: 'Dark of the Moon,' Appalachian drama.

1947-03-12.description: Truman asks Congress for $400 million for Greece and Turkey. Cold War policy begins.

1947-03-28.description: 24 inches of snow. Heaviest snowfall in 50 years. City paralyzed for a week.

1947-06-05.description: Secretary Marshall proposes European Recovery Program at Harvard commencement.

1947-06-15.event: Thomas Wolfe's childhood home opens as memorial
1947-06-15.description: 'Old Kentucky Home' boarding house becomes museum. 52 Spruce Street.

1947-06-23.description: Congress overrides Truman veto. Restricts labor unions. Allows right-to-work laws.

1947-07-26.description: Creates CIA, National Security Council, unified Department of Defense.

1947-08-20.event: Asheville-Biltmore College moves to new campus
1947-08-20.description: College relocates to former Asheville Junior High building on Victoria Road.

1948-04-03.description: Foreign Assistance Act provides $12 billion for European reconstruction.

1948-05-15.description: New terminal opens. Daily flights to Charlotte, Atlanta, Washington.

1948-07-05.event: Summer Arts Festival at Black Mountain College
1948-07-05.description: Buckminster Fuller, Merce Cunningham, John Cage in residence. National attention.

1948-07-26.description: Truman orders equality of treatment in armed forces. Begins military integration.

1948-11-02.description: 'Dewey Defeats Truman' headline wrong. Truman wins upset victory with 49.6%.
Truman wins upset. Buncombe supports Democrat 19,000 to 15,000.

1949-01-22.description: Temperature drops to -16°F. Coldest day on record. Pipes frozen citywide.

1949-04-04.description: North Atlantic Treaty Organization created. U.S. joins European defense alliance.

1949-05-30.event: Blue Ridge Parkway section opens near Asheville
1949-05-30.description: New section from Oteen to Craggy Gardens opens. Scenic views draw crowds.

1949-07-21.description: Senate votes 82-13 for North Atlantic Treaty. Historic departure from isolationism.

1949-10-01.description: Mao Zedong declares communist victory. 'Who lost China?' debate rocks U.S. politics.

1949-10-15.description: First parking meters on Pack Square. Nickel for one hour. Controversy ensues.

1950-02-09.description: Senator claims 205 communists in State Department. McCarthyism era begins.

1950-04-01.description: Population 53,000, slight increase. County 128,000. Suburbanization begins.

1950-06-25.description: North Korea invades South. UN authorizes military action.

1950-06-28.description: Local reservists await call-up. Korean veterans speak at courthouse rally.

1950-09-23.event: Internal Security Act passed over veto
1950-09-23.description: McCarran Act requires communist organizations to register. Truman vetoes, Congress overrides.

1950-10-15.description: First television station in Western NC. Channel 13. Studios on Sunset Mountain.

1951-02-26.description: Limits presidents to two terms. Reaction to FDR's four elections.

1951-03-15.description: New subdivisions in North Asheville. 500 homes under construction.

1951-06-10.event: Charles Olson named rector of Black Mountain College
1951-06-10.description: Poet takes leadership of troubled college. Enrollment declining.

1951-10-01.description: Blue Ridge Parkway packed with leaf-lookers. Record tourism predicted.

1952-03-21.description: Rare March tornado damages homes in Fairview. 3 injured.

1952-06-27.event: Immigration and Nationality Act passed over veto
1952-06-27.description: McCarran-Walter Act maintains national origins quotas. Truman vetoes, Congress overrides.

1952-08-16.event: Cage and Cunningham perform at Black Mountain College
1952-08-16.description: Experimental 'Theatre Piece No. 1' performed. Considered first 'Happening.'

1952-11-04.description: Ike defeats Adlai Stevenson with 55.2%. First Republican president since Hoover.
First Republican presidential vote since 1928. Ike wins county 22,000 to 20,000.

1953-05-01.event: Korean War ends; Asheville soldiers return
1953-05-01.description: Armistice celebrations muted. 47 Buncombe County men killed in action.

1953-07-27.description: Fighting ends after 3 years. 36,000 Americans dead. Korea remains divided.

1953-09-10.description: Downtown improvement project. New sidewalks, lighting, benches planned.

1954-05-17.event: Brown v. Board of Education decided
1954-05-17.description: Supreme Court rules 'separate but equal' unconstitutional. School segregation banned.

1954-05-18.event: Asheville reacts to Brown v. Board
1954-05-18.description: School board meets on integration ruling. No immediate action planned.

1954-08-30.description: Hurricane Hazel brings heavy rain. French Broad floods. 2 deaths in county.

1954-12-02.description: Senate votes 67-22 to condemn McCarthy for conduct 'contrary to Senate traditions.'

1954-12-15.description: Developers announce shopping center for Tunnel Road. First in region.

1955-03-15.description: College nearly bankrupt. Only 15 students enrolled. Closure discussed.

1955-08-17.description: Remnants of Diane cause severe flooding. $2 million damage in region.

1955-09-01.description: School year begins with no integration. NAACP threatens lawsuit.

1955-12-01.description: Rosa Parks arrested. Black community boycotts buses. Martin Luther King Jr. emerges as leader.

1956-06-29.description: Creates Interstate Highway System. 41,000 miles planned. Largest public works in history.

1956-06-30.description: Federal highway to pass through Asheville. Route through mountains debated.

1956-09-04.event: First Black students enter Asheville schools
1956-09-04.description: Asheville becomes first NC city to integrate schools. 4 students enter previously white schools.

1956-10-01.event: Black Mountain College enters final months
1956-10-01.description: Only 9 students remain. Faculty departed. Closure imminent.

1956-11-06.description: Ike defeats Stevenson again with 57.4%. Largest popular vote margin since 1936.

1957-01-15.description: City makes final payment on 1920s bonds. 27 years of debt ended.

1957-06-15.event: Grove Arcade sold to federal government
1957-06-15.description: Landmark building becomes federal offices. Stores relocated.

1957-09-04.event: Little Rock Nine blocked from school
1957-09-04.description: Arkansas Governor Faubus uses National Guard to prevent integration at Central High.

1957-09-09.description: First civil rights law since 1875. Creates Civil Rights Commission. Protects voting rights.

1957-09-24.event: Eisenhower sends troops to Little Rock
1957-09-24.description: 101st Airborne Division escorts Little Rock Nine into Central High School.

1957-10-21.description: Experimental college closes after 24 years. Property sold to pay debts.
